dataset.title: Oxygen-argon dissolved gas ratios using Equilibrator Inlet Mass Spectrometry (EIMS) and triple oxygen isotopes (TOI) from NES-LTER Transect cruises, ongoing since 2018

abstract.para: In order to calculate net community production (NCP) rates on Northeast U.S. Shelf Long-Term Ecological Research (NES-LTER) transect cruises, gas tracer data were collected with a continuous at-sea mass spectrometer. The ratio of O2/Ar, measured continuously from underway water, yields 8,000-15,000 rates of NCP per cruise. Discrete water samples (50 to 150 per cruise) were collected for triple oxygen isotope (TOI) analysis to estimate gross primary production (GPP) rates and ratios of NCP/GPP. Along-shelf (upstream-downstream) transects were conducted in addition to the main across-shelf transect. This data package provides two types of data tables for NES-LTER transect cruises beginning in 2018: a high-frequency continuous Equilibration Inlet Mass Spectrometer (EIMS) table, provided by year, and a low-frequency discrete triple oxygen isotope (TOI) table with all years combined. Rates calculated from these measurements are provided as separate packages, per year, in the EDI repository.

description.para: # Underway science seawater supplied to the Equilibrator Inlet Mass Spectrometer (EIMS)

A custom-built EIMS system was configured for automated measurement of oxygen and argon concentrations in the uncontaminated seawater flow in the ship’s lab. The system consists of a Hiden Hal 3F quadrupole mass spectrometer, compact pumping station for the mass spectrometer, equilibrator cartridge and various small pumps for air and water. Measurements were made approximately every 30 seconds. On cruise EN608, measurements were made with a Pfeiffer Prismaplus quadrupole mass spectrometer approximately every 12 seconds. Continuously during R/V Endeavor cruises, underway science seawater was supplied from 5-m water depth by two separate pumps: a diaphragm pump and an impeller pump; when possible we supplied water to the EIMS from the diaphragm pump. The Endeavor underway lines are not bleached but rather are flushed with freshwater before each cruise. On R/V Neil Armstrong cruises, underway science seawater was supplied from 2.13-m water depth by a diaphragm pump.
# Bottle sample seawater supplied post-cruise to mass spectrometer

Discrete samples for triple oxygen isotopes (TOI) and for additional measurements of O2/Ar ratios were collected from the underway science seawater supplied by diaphragm pump and from the water column at multiple depths using Niskin bottles on a CTD rosette system. Niskin bottles were checked for integrity with respect to gases. Samples are collected in custom-made 500-mL evacuated glass sample bottles that have been poisoned previously with 100 μL saturated mercuric chloride solution (Emerson et al. 1999). Samples were processed post-cruise for TOI following the methods of Stanley et al. (2015).
# Calibrations and derivations

The EIMS data have been calibrated according to the ratio measured in air roughly every 6 hours. This provides the calibrated O2/Ar ratio, which can be used to calculate rates of NCP (see Related packages, below). Biological saturation, or biosat, the percent supersaturation or undersaturation of O2 due to biological factors, is calculated as the calibrated O2/Ar ratio divided by the equilibrium value of O2/Ar (which is based on temperature and salinity) and expressed as a percentage. The EIMS data table includes high-frequency air-corrected O2/Ar ratio and the biological saturation value for the underway data. The TOI bottle data table consists of O2/Ar and TOI data for the bottle samples. Note that in some cases a rosette bottle at the surface and an underway discrete may be taken at approximately the same time, thus two rows in the discrete (low-frequency) table would match in time to one row in the underway (high-frequency) table.
# Data cleaning and assembly

PI Stanley exported a subset of columns from Matlab format into csv format for input to the workflow to assemble this data package; these input data files are provided as zip files. Data cleaning and metadata template assembly were performed in R Markdown. For the TOI bottle samples, a column was added to indicate whether the bottle was sampled from underway or Niskin. The package input data used Niskin = 0 and depth = 0 to signify underway samples; in the data product, this depth of underway samples is converted from 0 m to the depth of the ship's underway intake. For underway samples from R/V Endeavor, depth is 5 meters below the sea surface. For underway samples from R/V Neil Armstrong, depth is 2.13 meters below the sea surface. For bottle samples from Niskins, depth is supplied from the REST API bottle summary (i.e., measured depth) which is more accurate than depth_matlab. Additionally, cast number was supplied from the REST API bottle summary and the date-time (in UTC) was corrected to reflect the time at which the rosette bottle closed in contrast to the provided cast start time. Any records with the following conditions were excluded from the data product: a cast start time or a Niskin not found in API bottle summary, a time difference from API bottle summary record greater than 60 minutes or a depth difference greater than 5 m, a missing time value, a Niskin sample with a provided depth of zero, or an underway sample with a nonzero provided depth. In the EIMS data set, two records measured precisely at midnight have been omitted due to the lack of time code conversion. Further documentation can be found on GitHub, at https://github.com/WHOIGit/nes-lter-eims-toi-ncp-gop.
On cruise AR31A, a 24-position Niskin rosette was used with 12-bottle reporting, and provided Niskin number is adjusted to align the two recording systems.
# Quality assurance

We checked each cruise event log to confirm time periods of continuous EIMS and number of discrete TOI underway (and rosette logs to confirm number of discrete TOI Niskin). We identified and excluded TOI data when a provided datetime, location, depth, or Niskin number was unexpected, excluded EIMS data when time was missing, and plotted data for visual inspection. We assured that the geographic and temporal coverage of the clean data table were within expected ranges.
# Additional cruise notes
AR31A: Approximately 10 hrs of high-frequency data are missing (2018-10-22 from 12:41 to 22:20).

AR34B: Some high-frequency data are missing from the first and last days of the cruise. No underway TOI data are available for this cruise due to contamination. Niskin TOI data are included in the package.
# Differences from previous version

Version 3 adds several cruises. Discrete sample rows identified in the quality assurance steps are retained while flagging them as 3 (questionable) or 4 (bad). A correction was made to EN617 high-frequency data to align them with discrete bottle values, and one EN617 discrete sample (2018-07-24 15:33) previously labeled as sourced from Niskin was corrected to underway. Column headers for date/time, latitude, longitude, and depth are edited to remove references to Matlab, instead using the word "input" where needed to distinguish from NES-LTER API-derived metadata.

Verson 2 adds 2 cruises (AR31A and AR34B), excludes rows in previous version toi-transect csv for reasons described above (see toi_bottle_excluded.csv in GitHub referenced above), and retains 0 when applicable in depth_matlab column.
# Related packages
Net community production (NCP) and gross oxygen production (GOP) are derived from these data and published separately on a per-year basis to the EDI repository as follows (year, package ID):
2018, knb-lter-nes.13.3 2019, knb-lter-nes.14.3 2020, knb-lter-nes.30.1 2021, knb-lter-nes.31.1 2022, knb-lter-nes.32.1
# References

Emerson, S., C. Stump, D. Wilbur, and P. Quay. 1999. Accurate measurement of O-2, N-2, and Ar gases in water and the solubility of N-2. Mar. Chem. 64:337-347. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0304-4203(98)00090-5

Stanley, Rachel H.R., Zoe O. Sandwith, William J. Williams. 2015. Rates of summertime biological productivity in the Beaufort Gyre: A comparison between the low and record-low ice conditions of August 2011 and 2012. Journal of Marine Systems 147:29-44. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jmarsys.2014.04.006

abstract.para: The Northeast U.S. Shelf (NES) Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) project integrates observations, experiments, and models to understand and predict how planktonic food webs are changing, and how those changes impact the productivity of higher trophic levels. The NES-LTER is co-located with the Northeast U.S. Continental Shelf Large Marine Ecosystem, spanning the Middle Atlantic Bight and Gulf of Maine. Our focal cross-shelf transect extends about 150 km southward from Martha’s Vineyard, MA, to just beyond the shelf break. Our overarching question is: How is climate change impacting the pelagic NES ecosystem and, in particular, affecting the relationship between compositional (e.g., species diversity and size structure) and aggregate (e.g., rates of primary production, and transfer of energy to important forage fish species) variability?
